title: Political Reflections Arising Out Of My Sojourn In Vienna

slides.title: Introduction: Hitler's Emerging Political Views
content: Public political involvement should wait until age thirty, it allows time to gather knowledge.
A solid personal WELTANSCHAUUNG provides foundation for consistent political views.
Premature entry leads to policy reversals or defense of unsustainable positions.
Parliamentary deputies often fight heroically for their livelihood within existing systems.
slides.script: Welcome! This chapter covers Hitler's political reflections during his time in Vienna. He discusses the appropriate age to enter politics and lays the groundwork for his worldview. We will explore his critiques of the parliamentary system and the role of the individual in the state.

slides.title: Vienna: A Crucible for Understanding Humanity
content: Vienna provided valuable experience for studying diverse thought and human nature.
He was insulated from narrow bourgeois opinions and exposed to a wider social world.
He saw the difficulties Germans faced preserving their culture in Austria.
Early experiences in Vienna proved pivotal in his ideological development, exposing new social problems.
slides.script: Here, we look at the role Vienna played in his early political development. He emphasizes that Vienna gave him an understanding of various groups and also the role of the struggle for German language and culture played in Austria. From his observations in the streets of Vienna, Hitler would further cement his world view.

slides.title: The Austrian State: A Failing Experiment
content: The Austrian state depended on German leadership, with their wide scope.
Ten million Germans could not hold together an Empire of fifty-two million, because of its inherent problems.
A centralized government was the only potential solution, which was ultimately unattained.
The Habsburg rulers neglected the need to unify the state, ultimately dooming the empire.
slides.script: This slide examines Hitler's perspectives on the failing Austrian state. He argues the state could only be held together with a strong central government led by Germans, but this didn't happen. This ultimately contributed to its downfall. The Habsburg rulers failed to understand this concept, he argues.

slides.title: Parliamentary Weakness: An Indictment
content: Hitler criticizes Austrian parliament due to lack of responsibility and low intellectual level.
Parliamentarians focused on petty personal gains and lacked statesmanship.
He was a precocious revolutionary in art and politics in the Austrian State.
He thought the Hapsburgs betrayed the German people for personal gains in Austria.
slides.script: Hitler was very critical of parliament. He saw it as failing because it allowed people to avoid responsibility and attract petty, selfish politicians. It also gave the Hapsburgs the ability to betray the German people.

slides.title: Trades Unions: A Necessary Evil?
content: Trades Unions can benefit workers if used to improve conditions.
However, they're often co-opted for political class struggle.
Employers' refusal to address workers' legitimate demands contributes to union's radicalization.
The Social Democrats exploited workers, using them as cannon fodder in class warfare.
slides.script: Trades Unions have the potential to be an instrument of the people, as long as they are not used for political class struggle. Employers cause trouble and allow the unions to be co-opted by the Social Democrats.

slides.title: Trades Unions: A Defense of National Interests
content: Trades Unions should defend the national economy; the needs of the worker need not cross this.
However, skilled political pressure is often possible when one side lacks scruples.
He observed the 'Free Trades Union' as an instrument of social pressure, but also the worker.
The author's view is that Trades Unions threaten the security of the national economic structure.
slides.script: It is a matter of practicality, says Hitler. Skilled pressure and a lack of scruples can allow for the trampling of national economics in order to give the unions the upper hand in a political campaign. And the Trades Union is yet another threat to German stability.

slides.title: The Value of Nationalizing a Population
content: Nationalization of a people requires a healthy social environment.
Family, schools must instill cultural, economic, political greatness for patriotism to develop.
One can only love what one respects, and one can only respect what one knows.
Media spreads poison through theatre, cinema, journalism; thus, the public is left with no moral standards.
slides.script: In order for a country to become truly nationalized, it must have the moral fortitude in its members and also be taught cultural pride through family and in school. But that is being torn apart by the media.

slides.title: Early Awareness of Marxism and Judaism
content: He realized two major perils: Marxism and Judaism.
Vienna was naturally a festive place for happy mortals, but a sad place for me.
Five years of poverty in Vienna led to more learning, insight than expected, and an outlook that still sticks.
Youth is the time to lay the groundwork for creative thought; later years are more for wisdom.
slides.script: Poverty and the struggle to subsist in Vienna gave Hitler the impetus to explore the problems of Marxism and Judaism, with the effect it had on him and the people around him, which became the foundation for his later actions and thought.

slides.title: Vienna: Poverty and its Lessons
content: Exposure to poverty shattered his bourgeois education; he learned to see beyond appearances.
Vienna's extreme wealth and destitution made it an ideal place to study social problems.
Social problems cannot be truly understood from above; one must experience them.
Social activity must aim to eliminate fundamental deficiencies, not just charitable relief.
slides.script: This slide underscores the impact of poverty on Hitler's perspectives. He asserts that experiencing poverty is essential to truly understand social problems. This experience gave him insight he argues, that a person can only understand life by being steeped in it.

slides.title: Encountering Social Democracy and Marxism
content: First encounter with Social Democracy, saw only a struggle for suffrage; little knowledge of Marxism.
Estranged by hostility to Germanism and lamentable cocotting with the slavs, who are the real benefactors.
Suddenly faced with products of their teaching and Weltanschauung.
Social democracy, love of neighbor, and a pestilence spreading; it may exterminate the human race.
slides.script: Hitler claims that at the beginning of his journey, he had little knowledge of Social Democracy or Marxism. His interactions with it while working changed his point of view to one of extreme enmity toward the movement.

slides.title: Encountering Jews in Marxism
content: Examining Social Democratic Press revealed inner character better than theoretical literature.
He now believed in a system for poisoning the public mind.
Psychology of the masses favors strong, uncompromising teaching.
Terrorism tactics against the bourgeoisie are effective, until matched by ruthless response; as it is 'to be or not to be'.
slides.script: As he examined the Social Democrat Party, he saw the inner workings and recognized that the organization used terrorism against the people it governed and was full of people that wanted to dominate the world. In short, the Jews.

slides.title: The Jew: The Root of the Problem
content: Knowledge of the Jews is the key to understanding Social Democracy's aims.
Distinguishing between those fighting, hedgers, and traitors, even in schools.
Schools were a battleground for children, children were targets.
Growing up, he expressed his loyalty to Germany in the face of punishment, but his inclination favored the concept of folk.
slides.script: Hitler claims that his anti-semitic view started to take shape in his teen years and the school was one of the many venues where the struggle played out. And he became fully German and not a hedger.

slides.title: The Jew as a Catalyst for Hate
content: He first saw the Jew as a man of a different religion; later, realized they were an entirely different people.
The Zionist movement confirmed the national character of Judaism.
Underneath their unclean exterior he perceived the moral mildew of the chosen race.
Jewish activities in press, art, literature, theater became grave. It has always been clear that the Jew is not German.
slides.script: Now Hitler states that Jewish people are an entirely different race with an unclean exterior and whose activities in the arts have become grave. It was clear that Jewish people are not German at all.

slides.title: The Jew as a Revolutionary Force
content: He realized the Jews led Social Democracy.
The sojourn had convinced him that no worker can be that obstinate that he will not surrender.
But the Jew can never be rescued from his fixed notions.
In standing guard against the Jew, am defending the handiwork of the Lord.
slides.script: He came to discover that the Jews are behind the evil spirits that led his people astray, that is, the Social Democratic movement, which could never be convinced by arguing with them. And that in standing guard against the Jew, he is defending the work of God.

slides.title: Conclusion: An Unwavering Path
content: Early conclusions never abandoned: dissolution of Austria is a condition for Germany, nation > dynasty.
He also had an intense love for his German-Austrian home and a hatred for the Austrian State.
History taught him about the Hapsburg and other policies; He did not 'learn' but lets the history teach him.
A precocious revolutionary in art, a profound aversion to his father's plans, I should never be happy.
slides.script: His experiences in Vienna cemented his core beliefs: Austria needed to be dissolved, it had not done good for the German nation. and from then, history taught him, that is, politics, with an aversion to everything he did not agree with.
